title: The Ultimate Mindful Eaters Guide to Processed Foods
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
You would think that humans are an expert on nutrition, considering we’ve been on Earth and eating for over 300,000 years! Yet as time and technology trots on, our expansive knowledge of the biology of ourselves and food simply confuses us when it concerns... what to eat tonight.


[[1.jpg]]

Whole vs. Ultra-Processed Foods


The internet is ablaze with opinions of physicians, nutritionists, wellness experts, “influencers” and a never-ending cohort debating the question of which is better; whole foods or processed foods? In this article, let’s simplify the jargon and misconceptions, find reliable facts and come to a clearer understanding on how to better our diets together. This is the ultimate mindful eaters guide to processed foods.   


Whole Foods are classified as Processed Foods!

Bet you didn’t see that coming... The most comprehensive guide to food classification is NOVA. It categorises based on how much it has been processed and what we intend to use it for. It does not count calories and nutrients, therefore allowing us to grasp the concept of food from production to plate.


[[2.jpg]]

Everything, and we mean everything, that you eat, has undergone some level of processing.


Raw, natural, organic... They're all misnomers. When you pick a lime from your garden and wash it, that’s processing. When you blanch broccoli, that’s processing. When you wrap your vegetables in a KALIKA to extend shelf life, that’s processing. But you don’t want to eat a dirty lime or raw broccoli, do you?


The Ultimate Guide to Processed Foods: The different levels of processing

In this article, we’d like to share our knowledge on how to distinguish the different levels of processing the foods we eat undergo. Here is a summary of NOVA’s classification. 


Group 1: Unprocessed or minimally processed

[[3.jpg]]


What? Parts of plants and animals you can eat. Even fungi!


How? Removing inedible parts, drying, crushing, grinding, filtering, roasting, boiling, pasteurisation, refrigeration, vacuum sealing and non-alcoholic fermentation. These don't involve adding substances to the food like oil, salt or sugar but aims to extend their shelf life. Although they rarely contain additives, some milk undergone pasteurisation might have added stabilisers.


Examples? Fresh, squeezed, frozen or dried fruits and vegetables, grains, legumes, fresh or dried mushrooms, meat, eggs, milk, unsweetened fruit or vegetable juices, flour from corn, wheat, oats or cassava, pasta, nuts, seeds, herbs, spices, plain yoghurt, tea, coffee and water.



Group 2: Processed culinary ingredients

[[oil.jpg]]


What? These are Group 1 converted into products used in food preparation, seasoning and cooking. It can be used in home-cooked dishes, soups, broths, breads, preserves, salads, drinks and desserts. They may contain preservatives to retain the original product's properties or to prevent bacterial growth.


How? Pressing, refining, grinding, milling and spray drying. They are often consumed together with Group 1.


Examples? Salt, sugar, honey, syrup, vegetable oils, butter, starches, vinegar.



Group 3: Processed Foods

[[5.jpg]]

12 canned food products that can be healthy


What? A love child of Group 1 and Group 2, Group 3 typically contains 2-3 ingredients. It is made to be more durable and taste better. They definitely contain additives to prevent spoilage. 


How? It uses a combination of preservation or cooking methods to make products that are canned, bottled, salted, sugared and treated. Canned beans are high in sodium, which can lead to increased blood pressure so be sure to rinse the beans thoroughly first, and season with more herbs and spices than salt. 


Examples? Canned beans, fish, fruits, vegetables, cured or smoked meat, cheese and freshly made bread. If you think of alcohol as food, then it’s Group 3.


Group 4: Ultra-processed food and drink products.

[[6.jpg]]

Eating junk food increases risk of depression, study says


What? It should be cause for concern that a legitimate food classification system calls this an "industrial formulation". Primarily aiming to make ready-to-eat and artificially delicious foods, hallmarks of this food group are attractive packaging, aggressive marketing and questionable health claims. It contains five or more ingredients such as oils, sugars, fats, salt, stabilisers, flavouring, colouring, preservatives etc.


How? Extrusion, moulding and pre-processing for frying. Not concepts Grandma would be familiar with… 


Examples? Carbonated drinks, sweet or savoury snacks, ice-cream, chocolate, candies, mass-produced breads, margarines, spreads, cookies, pastries, cakes, cake mixes, breakfast cereals, energy bars or drinks, instant sauces and gravy, dairy-containing drinks, cocoa drunks, meat extracts, infant formulas, health and slimming products, pre-made pies, pasta, pizza, meat nuggets, sticks, sausages, burgers, hot dogs, powdered soups, noodles, desserts. What a mouthful!



[[7.png]]

A useful infographic to help explain processed foods by Chris Vogliano, MS RD


Overwhelmed? Don’t worry! Here are some easy-to-follow rules;

👍 If you can tell that it’s real food by looking at it, eat. 

👎 If it looks like it was grown in a chemistry lab, avoid.

👍 If it has a label with a few ingredients that you can pronounce, eat.

👎 If a celebrity on the package boasts magnanimous health benefits, avoid.﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿


﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿Are Whole Foods Better than Ultra-Processed Foods?

Well… They are higher in nutrients, fibre, healthy fats and lower in salt, sugar, unhealthy fats. They are better for the environment as there is much less industrial energy spent on processing and packaging. They are better for the local economy if you shop at a farmer’s market. They promote eating more home-cooked meals which is healthier than eating out. What do you think?


[[8.jpg]]

Processed Food and Health


The Mediterranean diet, which comprises mostly whole foods, is the most recommended diet for optimal health. Our bodies are adapted to thriving on whole foods. Therefore, our gut health is more suited to eating whole foods, whatmore natural sources of probiotics are garlic and cocoa. 


[[9.png]]

More than half of the diet of the American population is processed food


Processed and ultra-processed food are more calorie-dense as opposed to nutrient-dense. So, you tend to overeat to satisfy your nutrient quota, as a recent study found. It is agreed upon by NOVA, and the health promoting community to avoid this group of food as much as possible. 


But processed foods are not all bad if used responsibly! 


Say, if you’re trying to reduce your meat intake by switching to canned chickpeas. Or if you’re a compulsive snacker opting for a healthier snack rather than forcing yourself to kick the habit. Or if your dose of daily greens is a pre-made salad. Worry only if you’re always reheating meals that resemble Play-Doh more than real food.


So, to wrap up...

[[10.jpg]]

Oh, don’t we all wish it were so simple?


We hope this article gave you some insight and cleared the confusion surrounding processed food. Processed food is not the enemy here, but a lack of awareness of what happens to our food from its origin to our mouths. Knowing the different levels of processing lets us be the one to decide what we actually consume.


Rather than counting calories, obsessing over diet fads and our weight, let’s focus instead on creating a sustainable and wholesome diet instead. The Brazilian Dietary Guidelines follow a Golden Rule that we too can live by; 


“Always prefer natural or minimally processed foods and freshly made dishes and meals to ultra-processed products.”
